column3: How and Why to Start and Run a SIGCHI Local Chapter
column19: Department of Computer Science and Information Systems
column166: There is a vast and increasing interest towards local HCI communities around the globe and in particular on geographical areas in which HCI has only recently started to gain increasing interest by local industries as well as academic institutions. A SIGCHI Local Chapter is one of the ways a local HCI community can organize and get visibility and support for their activities. However, many active volunteers in this field might not be aware of this possibility. The main goal of the Chapters’ SIG in CHI’15 is to inform interested parties of SIGCHI Local Chapters and to find ways in which SIGCHI could better support local HCI communities with their various needs all over the world.

Kujala, T. (2014). SIGCHI local chapters in 2014. interactions, 21(4). \ 3. Szostek, A. & Kujala, T. (2014). CHI Poland – a network of local chapters. interactions, 21(2). \ 4. Prates, R., Barbosa, S., Silveira, M., Souza, C., Baranauskas, C., Maciel, C., et al. (2013). HCI community in Brazil - sweet 16! interactions, 20(6), 8081. \ 5. Williams, S., Jacobson, F., Frisberg, N., & Kujala, T. (2013). BayCHI: Serving the Bay Area CHI community for over 20 years. interactions, 20(4). \ 6. Kujala, T. & Häkkilä, J. (2013). User experiences from the land of a thousand lakes. interactions, 20(2).
column168: Human-Computer Interaction (HCI); special interest group; local community
column174: SIGCHI Local Chapter is one of the ways a local HCI community can organize and get visibility and support for their activities. Come to network and learn more!

column3: Design for Online Deliberative Processes and Technologies: Towards a Multidisciplinary Research Agenda
column12: Weiyu Zhang, Lu Xiao, Anna Przybylska, Anna De Liddo, Gregorio Convertino, Todd Davies, Mark Klein
column13: weiyu.zhang@nus.edu.sg, lxiao24@uwo.ca, a.przybylska@uw.edu.pl, a.deliddo@gmail.com, gconvertino@gmail.com, davies@stanford.edu, m_klein@mit.edu
column19: Communications and New Media, Faculty of Arts and Social Science
column49: Center for Deliberation, Institute of Sociology
column166: There has been rapidly growing interest in studying and designing online deliberative processes and technologies. This SIG aims at providing a venue for continuous and constructive dialogue between social, political and cognitive sciences as well as computer science, HCI, and CSCW. Through an online community and a modified version of world cafe discussions, we contribute to the definition of the theoretical building blocks, the identification of a research agenda for the CHI community, and the network of individuals from academia, industry, and the public sector who share interests in different aspects of online deliberation.

Large Scale Idea Management and Deliberation Systems at C&T 2013. http://www.gi2mo.org/2013/ \ 4. Fourth International Conference on Online Deliberation. http://www.od2010.di.unimi.it/ \ 5. The First Essence09 Workshop. http://events.kmi.open.ac.uk/essence/index.html \ 6. ODET 2010: Online Deliberation Emerging Tools. http://www.olnet.org/odet2010 \ 7. First Workshop on Argumentation Mining. http://www.uncg.edu/cmp/ArgMining2014/ \ 8. Large-Scale Ideation and Deliberation: Tools and Studies in Organizations. https://www.mitre.org/jsmo \
column168: Argumentation; collective intelligence; deliberation system; ideation; social innovation
column174: Come join a group of computer scientists and social scientists for an integrated online and on-site discussion event about design and evaluation of online deliberative technologies and processes!
column181: Natural Sciences & Engineering Research Discovery Programme

column3: Understanding Sports-HCI by Going Jogging at CH
column12: Florian Mueller, Joe Marshall, Rohit Ashok Khot, Stina Nylander, Jakob Tholander
column166: More and more technologies are emerging that aim to support sports activities, for example there are jogging apps, cycling computers and quadcopters for sportspeople to videorecord their actions. These new technologies appear to become more and more popular, yet interaction design knowledge how to support the associated exertion experiences is still limited. In order to bring practitioners and academics interested in sports-HCI together and examine the topic “in the wild”, we propose to go outside and jog around the CHI venue while using and discussing some of these new technologies. The goal is to investigate and shape the future of the field of sports-HCI.

column169: H.5.2. [Information Interfaces and Presentation]: User Interfaces
column173: Understanding sports-HCI by going jogging at CHI.
column174: Bring your sports gear as we will be jogging around the CHI venue to discuss Sports-HCI! Seriously.

column3: SIG: Gender-Inclusive Software: What We Know About Building It
column12: Margaret M Burnett, Elizabeth F Churchill, Michael J Lee
column166: Recent research has shown that some software that is intended to be gender-neutral is not, in fact, equally inclusive to males and females.  But little is known about how to design software in a gender-aware fashion, and existing research on gender differences relevant to software design is scattered across at least five different academic fields (e.g., psychology, computer science, education, communications, and women's studies).  This research SIG will bring together female and male academics, industry researchers, and practitioners with three goals in mind: (1) to build community across research/practice boundaries; (2) to pool our knowledge on promising practices for design and evaluation of software from a gender perspective; and (3) to begin to build a shared, on-line research and literature base to support solid, well-informed progress on this important issue.

column168: Women; feminism; gender; Gender HCI; system design
column169: H.5.m. Information interfaces and presentation (e.g., HCI): Miscellaneous
column174: How do you build gender-inclusive software? This SIG will pool our knowledge and begin a shared, on-line resource base with promising practices for design and evaluation of gender-inclusive software.
